elements.content: The reaction of Cu(BF4)2 with pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2pydc) and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) under hydrothermal conditions afforded a porous mixed-valence CuICuII coordination polymer. Coexistence of tetrameric and decameric water clusters within the channels of the complex leads to a novel water chain. The metal−organic framework provides both hydrophilic and hydrophobic environments for stabilizing the clusters and retains its integrity upon dehydration and rehydration.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of Cu(BF4)2 with pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2pydc) and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) under hydrothermal conditions afforded a porous mixed-valence CuICuII coordination polymer. Coexistence of tetrameric and decameric water clusters within the channels of the complex leads to a novel water chain. The metal-organic framework provides both hydrophilic and hydrophobic environments for stabilizing the clusters and retains its integrity upon dehydration and rehydration.

elements.content: Coexistence of tetrameric and decameric water clusters within the channels of a porous mixed-valence CuICuII coordination polymer leads to a novel water chain. The metal−organic framework provides both hydrophilic and hydrophobic environments for stabilizing the clusters and retains its integrity upon dehydration and rehydration.
elements.clean_text: Coexistence of tetrameric and decameric water clusters within the channels of a porous mixed-valence CuICuII coordination polymer leads to a novel water chain. The metal-organic framework provides both hydrophilic and hydrophobic environments for stabilizing the clusters and retains its integrity upon dehydration and rehydration.

elements.content: Water plays a crucial role in many biological and chemical processes. Hydrogen-bonding interactions involving water molecules are the main driving forces that influence the structures and properties of host systems and water aggregates. The investigations of hydrogen-bonded water clusters (H2O) n have attracted a great deal of interest because they provide clues not only to unraveling the properties of bulk water in a molecular level but also to understanding the interactions of water aggregates and their surroundings. Theoretical studies have predicted the relative stability of various water clusters with varying size and geometry and some of them have been identified in crystal hosts. Among these clusters, cyclic tetramer is a common form, and there are a number of examples of the crystallographic observation of the tetramers in crystals. As compared with tetramer, water decamer requires larger space and specific environments in host matrix. On the basis of the vibrational OH stretch spectra and theoretical calculations, Buck et al. have proposed the possibility of a water decamer with a butterfly-shaped configuration, which can be viewed as an octameric cube with two extra water molecules inserted at opposite edges. The butterfly decamer has been confirmed by X-ray crystallography in an organic crystal host, although it is not the lowest energy structure. Another form of (H2O)10 cluster observed in the crystals of hydrated metal complexes possesses an adamantane-like structure similar to the smallest subunit of ice Ic. Although these findings have revealed structural aspects of the water tetramers and decamers, further information is needed for clarifying the formation and behavior of such clusters in diverse environments.
elements.clean_text: Water plays a crucial role in many biological and chemical processes. Hydrogen-bonding interactions involving water molecules are the main driving forces that influence the structures and properties of host systems and water aggregates. The investigations of hydrogen-bonded water clusters (H2O) n  have attracted a great deal of interest because they provide clues not only to unraveling the properties of bulk water in a molecular level but also to understanding the interactions of water aggregates and their surroundings. Theoretical studies have predicted the relative stability of various water clusters with varying size and geometry and some of them have been identified in crystal hosts. Among these clusters, cyclic tetramer is a common form, and there are a number of examples of the crystallographic observation of the tetramers in crystals. As compared with tetramer, water decamer requires larger space and specific environments in host matrix. On the basis of the vibrational OH stretch spectra and theoretical calculations, Buck et al. have proposed the possibility of a water decamer with a butterfly-shaped configuration, which can be viewed as an octameric cube with two extra water molecules inserted at opposite edges. The butterfly decamer has been confirmed by X-ray crystallography in an organic crystal host, although it is not the lowest energy structure. Another form of (H2O)10 cluster observed in the crystals of hydrated metal complexes possesses an adamantane-like structure similar to the smallest subunit of ice Ic. Although these findings have revealed structural aspects of the water tetramers and decamers, further information is needed for clarifying the formation and behavior of such clusters in diverse environments.

elements.content: Designed synthesis of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has been a great challenge in solid-state chemistry. One of the intriguing structural features of the MOFs is their porosity, which results in potential applications of these materials in ion exchange, molecular adsorption, and catalysis. The MOFs may provide alternative environments in cavities or channels for stabilizing the configurations of water clusters. It has been reported that copper(II) ion is reduced by pyridine derivatives under hydrothermal conditions to afford mixed-valence CuICuII species. In an attempt to prepare new MOFs by utilizing a combination of different connectivities of CuI and CuII centers, we have isolated a unique porous mixed-valence CuICuII coordination polymer [CuI 2CuII(pydc)2(bpe)2]·7H2O (1) [pydc = pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate; bpe = trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene]. Unprecedented one-dimensional (1D) water chains consisting of cyclic tetramers and butterfly decamers were observed in the channels of the complex.
elements.clean_text: Designed synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been a great challenge in solid-state chemistry. One of the intriguing structural features of the MOFs is their porosity, which results in potential applications of these materials in ion exchange, molecular adsorption, and catalysis. The MOFs may provide alternative environments in cavities or channels for stabilizing the configurations of water clusters. It has been reported that copper(II) ion is reduced by pyridine derivatives under hydrothermal conditions to afford mixed-valence CuICuII species. In an attempt to prepare new MOFs by utilizing a combination of different connectivities of CuI and CuII centers, we have isolated a unique porous mixed-valence CuICuII coordination polymer [CuI 2CuII(pydc)2(bpe)2]⋅7H2O (1) [pydc = pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate; bpe = trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene]. Unprecedented one-dimensional (1D) water chains consisting of cyclic tetramers and butterfly decamers were observed in the channels of the complex.

elements.content: The crystal structure analysis revealed that 1 consists of one divalent copper atom, two monovalent copper atoms, two bpe and two pydc ligands, and seven water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The divalent Cu1 atom in an octahedral geometry is coordinated by two pydc ligands forming a [CuII(pydc)2]2- metallo-ligand. Each monovalent Cu2 and Cu3 atom is coordinated by two symmetrically related bpe ligands in a nearly linear arrangement to form an extended chain. The two chains are cross-linked by the Cu1 metallo-ligand through two carboxylate groups that coordinate to Cu2 and Cu3, respectively, which generates a molecular ladder with rectangular voids (Figure a). These ladders are stacked parallel to one another along the [0 1 1̄] direction, stabilized by π−π interactions between the pyridyl rings of the pydc ligands from adjacent ladders, to give a 2D sheet with extended channels. The sheets are further stacked in the [0 1 1] direction through π−π interactions between the bpe ligands, as shown in Figure b.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure analysis revealed that 1 consists of one divalent copper atom, two monovalent copper atoms, two bpe and two pydc ligands, and seven water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The divalent Cu1 atom in an octahedral geometry is coordinated by two pydc ligands forming a [CuII(pydc)2]2- metallo-ligand. Each monovalent Cu2 and Cu3 atom is coordinated by two symmetrically related bpe ligands in a nearly linear arrangement to form an extended chain. The two chains are cross-linked by the Cu1 metallo-ligand through two carboxylate groups that coordinate to Cu2 and Cu3, respectively, which generates a molecular ladder with rectangular voids (Figure a). These ladders are stacked parallel to one another along the [0 1 1̄] direction, stabilized by π-π interactions between the pyridyl rings of the pydc ligands from adjacent ladders, to give a 2D sheet with extended channels. The sheets are further stacked in the [0 1 1] direction through π-π interactions between the bpe ligands, as shown in Figure b.

elements.content: Ladder-like coordination polymer (a) and crystal packing (b) in1, showing the channels along the [0 1 1̄] direction (Cu:  green; O:  red; N:  blue; C:  gray). Water molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Ladder-like coordination polymer (a) and crystal packing (b) in1, showing the channels along the [0 1 1̄] direction (Cu: green; O: red; N: blue; C: gray). Water molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: A surprise beyond the original crystal design is that 1D water chains with alternating (H2O)10 and (H2O)4 clusters exist in the channels. As shown in Figure , five water molecules (O1w to O5w) and their symmetric equivalents form a centrosymmetric cagelike decamer, which can be viewed as a cube formed by eight water molecules with two additional water molecules (O5w and O5wA) inserted at opposite edges. The 10 water molecules are held together by 14 hydrogen bonds, leaving six hydrogen atoms available for further hydrogen-bonding interactions with surroundings. The connectivity agrees well with that of the “butterfly” structure proposed by Buck et al. However, the hydrogen-bonding scheme in the present decamer is quite different from that of Buck's model and that found in an organic crystal host, which can be distinguished by the positions of six free hydrogen atoms (see Supporting Information). This indicates that the butterfly decamer is sufficiently flexible to respond to changes in environments. The cyclic water tetramer is formed by Ow6 and Ow7 and their centrosymmetrically related atoms. The tetramer adopts the uudd configuration, with four free hydrogen atoms in an up−up−down−down (uudd) fashion. Although the uudd configuration is energetically less stable compared to the energy minimum up−down−up−down (udud) configuration, it has been observed in the crystalline solids of metal complexes. The decamers and tetramers are linked through O5w−H···O6w hydrogen bonds to produce an extended chain passing through the channel.
elements.clean_text: A surprise beyond the original crystal design is that 1D water chains with alternating (H2O)10 and (H2O)4 clusters exist in the channels. As shown in Figure , five water molecules (O1w to O5w) and their symmetric equivalents form a centrosymmetric cagelike decamer, which can be viewed as a cube formed by eight water molecules with two additional water molecules (O5w and O5wA) inserted at opposite edges. The 10 water molecules are held together by 14 hydrogen bonds, leaving six hydrogen atoms available for further hydrogen-bonding interactions with surroundings. The connectivity agrees well with that of the "butterfly" structure proposed by Buck et al. However, the hydrogen-bonding scheme in the present decamer is quite different from that of Buck's model and that found in an organic crystal host, which can be distinguished by the positions of six free hydrogen atoms (see Supporting Information). This indicates that the butterfly decamer is sufficiently flexible to respond to changes in environments. The cyclic water  tetramer is formed by Ow6 and Ow7 and their centrosymmetrically related atoms. The tetramer adopts the uudd configuration, with four free hydrogen atoms in an up-up-down-down (uudd) fashion. Although the uudd configuration is energetically less stable compared to the energy minimum up-down-up-down (udud) configuration, it has been observed in the crystalline solids of metal complexes. The decamers and tetramers are linked through O5w-H⋅⋅⋅O6w hydrogen bonds to produce an extended chain passing through the channel.

elements.content: 1D water chain built of the tetramers and decamers, showing the uudd configuration of the tetramer and the butterfly configuration of the decamer. The atoms labeled with “A” are centrosymmetrically related to the original atoms. Dashed lines denote hydrogen bonds.
elements.clean_text: 2  1D water chain built of the tetramers and decamers, showing the uudd configuration of the tetramer and the butterfly configuration of the decamer. The atoms labeled with "A" are centrosymmetrically related to the original atoms. Dashed lines denote hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that there are two distinct types of pockets inside the channel (Figure ). One pocket is hydrophilic with four uncoordinated carboxylate O atoms pointing inward, thus leading to a smaller void space. The water tetramer occupies this pocket and forms four hydrogen bonds with the uncoordinated O atoms. The other pocket surrounded by pyridine rings exhibits hydrophobic character. The water decamer is accommodated in the hydrophobic pocket and sustained by hydrogen bonds formed between the water molecules and carboxylate O atoms in the neighboring hydrophilic pockets. There is a close contact of 3.17 Å between O4w and a pyridyl plane. Because two hydrogen atoms of O4w are involved in the cluster framework, we deduced that this contact is not an O−H···π but an O(lone pair)···π interaction. The butterfly decamer can be stabilized by donating lone pair electrons of O4w to the pyridyl group, which is electron-deficient due to metal coordination. A similar phenomenon has been observed for the adamantanoid decamer. The solvent-accessible volume calculated with the PLATON program in the hydrophilic pocket is 5.8% of the unit cell volume and that in the hydrophobic pocket is 15.6%. Thus, we can obtain effective densities of 1.002 g cm-3 for the tetramer and 0.923 g cm-3 for the decamer. These values imply that the tetramer is more efficient at occupying the hydrophilic pocket.
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to note that there are two distinct types of pockets inside the channel (Figure ). One pocket is hydrophilic with four uncoordinated carboxylate O atoms pointing inward, thus leading to a smaller void space. The water tetramer occupies this pocket and forms four hydrogen bonds with the uncoordinated O atoms. The other pocket surrounded by pyridine rings exhibits hydrophobic character. The water decamer is accommodated in the hydrophobic pocket and sustained by hydrogen bonds formed between the water molecules and carboxylate O atoms in the neighboring hydrophilic pockets. There is a close contact of 3.17 Å between O4w and a pyridyl plane. Because two hydrogen atoms of O4w are involved in the cluster framework, we deduced that this contact is not an O-H⋅⋅⋅π but an O(lone pair)⋅⋅⋅π interaction. The butterfly decamer can be stabilized by donating lone pair electrons of O4w to the pyridyl group, which is electron-deficient due to metal coordination. A similar phenomenon has been observed for the adamantanoid decamer. The solvent-accessible volume calculated with the PLATON program in the hydrophilic pocket is 5.8% of the unit cell volume and that in the hydrophobic pocket is 15.6%. Thus, we can obtain effective densities of 1.002 g cm-3 for the tetramer and 0.923 g cm-3 for the decamer. These values imply that the tetramer is more efficient at occupying the hydrophilic pocket.

elements.content: A side view of the channel in which the water molecules reside, showing that the hydrophilic pocket is occupied by the tetramer and the hydrophobic pocket is occupied by the decamer. The water−water hydrogen bonds are denoted by yellow solid lines and the water−carboxylate hydrogen bonds are denoted by red dashed lines (Cu:  green; O:  red; N:  blue; C:  gray). Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  A side view of the channel in which the water molecules reside, showing that the hydrophilic pocket is occupied by the tetramer and the hydrophobic pocket is occupied by the decamer. The water-water hydrogen bonds are denoted by yellow solid lines and the water-carboxylate hydrogen bonds are denoted by red dashed lines (Cu: green; O: red; N: blue; C: gray). Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The average O···O distance of 2.840 Å between water molecules is longer than that of 2.760 Å between water molecules and carboxylate groups. These values indicate that water−MOF interactions are stronger than those of water−water. Therefore, the water molecules can be divided into two types:  O1w, O3w, and O4w (type A) only form water−water hydrogen bonds, while the other four (type B) are involved in hydrogen bonds with carboxylates. When crystals of 1 were exposed in air, gradual loss of crystal transparency was observed, suggesting that the water molecules of type A may escape from the lattice and the heptahydrate 1 may change to a tetrahydrate. Indeed, thermal gravimetric analysis (see Supporting Information) of these crystals showed that the total water loss took place in one step between room temperature and 110 °C with a 7.49% weight loss, which corresponds well to four water molecules of type B (calculated 7.53% based on the tetrahydrate). The compound is stable up to 261 °C, at which decomposition of organic components occurs. The binding of water molecules to the MOF was also examined by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of the freshly prepared 1 and the samples heated at 100 °C for 5 and 7 h, respectively. The broad bands for OH stretching vibrations of the water clusters are centered at 3410, 3357, and 3313 cm-1, respectively, for the different heating times, and the intensity is weakened as heating time is increased (see Supporting Information). This can be attributed to the stepwise removal of the loosely bound water molecules during heating and is in agreement with the results from structure analysis.
elements.clean_text: The average O⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.840 Å between water molecules is longer than that of 2.760 Å between water molecules and carboxylate groups. These values indicate that water-MOF interactions are stronger than those of water-water. Therefore, the water molecules can be divided into two types: O1w, O3w, and O4w (type A) only form water-water hydrogen bonds, while the other four (type B) are involved in hydrogen bonds with carboxylates. When crystals of 1 were exposed in air, gradual loss of crystal transparency was observed, suggesting that the water molecules of type A may escape from the lattice and the heptahydrate 1 may change to a tetrahydrate. Indeed, thermal gravimetric analysis (see Supporting Information) of these crystals showed that the total water loss took place in one step between room temperature and 110 °C with a 7.49% weight loss, which corresponds well to four water molecules of type B (calculated 7.53% based on the tetrahydrate). The compound is stable up to 261 °C, at which decomposition of organic components occurs. The binding of water molecules to the MOF was also examined by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of the freshly prepared 1 and the samples heated at 100 °C for 5 and 7 h, respectively. The broad bands for OH stretching vibrations of the water clusters are centered at 3410, 3357, and 3313 cm-1, respectively, for the different heating times, and the intensity is weakened as heating time is increased (see Supporting Information). This can be attributed to the stepwise removal of the loosely bound water molecules during heating and is in agreement with the results from structure analysis.

elements.content: The removal and re-adsorption of water in 1 were investigated by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) (see Supporting Information). A comparison of XRPD patterns before and after expulsion of water revealed that a low-angle peak disappeared after heating the sample at 110 °C for 5 h, which suggests that the major contribution to this peak comes from the structured water. After the dehydrated sample was placed in a humidity container for 2 days, XRPD showed that the peak appeared again at the same position, indicating that the sample was rehydrated. The simulated XRPD patterns for 1 and the dehydrated structure show a similar situation. Therefore, 1 retains its porosity even after the removal of water, and the channel in 1 should play a significant role in the formation of the tetramer−decamer chain.
elements.clean_text: The removal and re-adsorption of water in 1 were investigated by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) (see Supporting Information). A comparison of XRPD patterns before and after expulsion of water revealed that a low-angle peak disappeared after heating the sample at 110 °C for 5 h, which suggests that the major contribution to this peak comes from the structured water. After the dehydrated sample was placed in a humidity container for 2 days, XRPD showed that the peak appeared again at the same position, indicating that the sample was rehydrated. The simulated XRPD patterns for 1 and the dehydrated structure show a similar situation. Therefore, 1 retains its porosity even after the removal of water, and the channel in 1 should play a significant role in the formation of the tetramer-decamer chain.

elements.content: In summary, we have identified a unique ladder-like mixed-valence CuICuII coordination polymer. The most interesting result is the observation of a novel water chain consisting of tetrameric and decameric water clusters. The MOF host provides both hydrophilic and hydrophobic environments to accommodate the tetramers and decamers. The size and shape of these water clusters are closely related to the volume and polarity of the void space in the channel. The present findings can improve our understanding of the interactions between host matrixes and water clusters.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have identified a unique ladder-like mixed-valence CuICuII coordination polymer. The most interesting result is the observation of a novel water chain consisting of tetrameric and decameric water clusters. The MOF host provides both  hydrophilic and hydrophobic environments to accommodate the tetramers and decamers. The size and shape of these water clusters are closely related to the volume and polarity of the void space in the channel. The present findings can improve our understanding of the interactions between host matrixes and water clusters.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format, hydrogen-bond parameters, TGA curve, IR spectra, and XRPD patterns for 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: The average O···O distance of 2.840 Å between water molecules is longer than that of 2.760 Å between water molecules and carboxylate groups. These values indicate that water−MOF interactions are stronger than those of water−water. Therefore, the water molecules can be divided into two types:  O1w, O3w, and O4w (type A) only form water−water hydrogen bonds, while the other four (type B) are involved in hydrogen bonds with carboxylates. metadata.title:
Self-Assembly of a Water Chain with Tetrameric and Decameric Clusters in the
Channel of a Mixed-Valence CuICuII Complex
